question: Which of the following is NOT a grass-root level worker?
exp: GRASS ROOT LEVEL WORKERS Anganwadi worker: Works at village level Traditional bih attendant: Works at village level Village health guide: Works at village level ASHA: Works at village level Multipurpose worker: Works at sub-centre (5 villages) level.
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Primary Urban Health Centre should be for a population of:
exp: URBAN HEALTH CARE DELIVERY MODEL :- Community level: Community outreach services. Sub-primary level: Swasthya chowki 1 Swasthya chowki per 10,000 population. 1 ANM + 1 Community health worker. Primary level: I Primary urban health Centre (PUHC) 1 PUHC/UHC per 50,000 (1 per 25000-30000 in slums). Referral level: Public or empanelled secondary / teiary care providers. Secondary level Urban Health Centre - Metros- 1 per 5,00,000 ; Non-metros - 1 per 2,50,000.
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: One Eye surgeon is recommended for:
exp: According to IPHS, one ophthalmologist is being envisaged for every 5 lakh population i.e. one ophthalmologist will center to 5 CHCs in India. ALSO REMEMBER: According to WHO, one ophthalmologist is being envisaged for every 50,000 population in every Asian country by 2020. 1 U-ANM, 1 Pharmacist, 1 Lab technician for 10,000 population. 1 USHA for 1000-2500 population.
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: A Trained bih attended is for a population of:
exp: National target: 1 TBA per village (1000 rural population) Traditional bih attendant (TBA) Location - village level Population norm - 1/1000 Education - NO Training at : PHC, sub - centre or MCH centre (30 working days: has to conduct 2 supervised deliveries) Duties of TBAs: 1) Conduct home deliveries in aseptic manner 2) Reduce IMR and MMR 3) Registration of both mother and child at sub - centre / PHC 4) Propagate small family norm.
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Training duration of Traditional bih attendant (TBA) is
exp: Traditional bih attendant (TBA) Location - village level Population norm - 1/1000 Education - NO Training - 30 days (1 months)
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Number of ASHA visits after home delivery is:
exp: ASHA: Acredited Social Health Activist - 25-45 yr old female worker, Works at village level - Should be resident of same village - Bridge b/w Village & ANM; Selected by village panchayat - Training is given by ANM & AWW - Impact indicators: Reduction of IMR TB cases detected Leprosy cases detected PEM rates - Number of ASHA visits: 6 visits in Institutional deliveries: On Day 3,7,14, 21,28,42 post-delivery 7 visits in Home based deliveries: On Day 1,3,7,14,21,28,42 post-delivery 5 visits in bihs through LSCS (no visit on day 1 & 3).
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Who looks after the work of Anganwadi worker?
exp: Mukhyasevika looks after the work of Anganwadi worker Administrative unit of ICDS-Community Development Block Each project covers population of 1,00,000 (rural/urban) or 35,000 (tribal) 1 CDPO (Community Development Project Officer) is in charge of 4 supervisors (Mukhyasevikas) and 100 Anganwadis (each supervisor for 25 Anganwadis).
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: One PHC is established per ____________ population in Tribal areas
exp: Population norms for health centres in india Primary health care system ICDS system Centre Sub- centre PHC CHC Anganwadi Level of care Primary Primary Secondary - Population norm Plains Hilly/tribal areas 5000 3000 30,000 20,000 1,20,000 80,000 400-800 300-800
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Which of the following are referred to as "Ivory Towers of Disease":
exp: - Hospitals are known as 'Ivory Towers of Disease', as they exist in Spending isolation in the community Absorb vast propoion (50-80%) of the health budget Not people oriented, are inflexible in procedures, styles and treatment is expensive it overlooks the cultural aspects of illness (treating the disease without treating the patient)
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Test done at sub Subcentre during pregnancy:
exp: Tests done at Sub center: Pregnancy detection test Hemoglobin level estimation Urine test for albumin and sugar Rapid malaria test Tests done at PHC/CHC/DH: Blood grouping with Rh HIV testing VDRL, RPR Rapid Malaria test Blood Sugar HBSAg.
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: True about incentives given to ASHA worker in Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram:
exp: Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) Incentives Category Rural area Urban area Mother's ASHA Mother's ASHA LPS 1400 600 1000 400 HPS 700 600 600 400
opa: 400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in rural area in high performing states
opb: 400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in rural area in low performing states
opc: 400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in urban area high performing states
opd: 400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in urban area low performing states
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Highest level of integration in health service is:-
exp: - Integrated health service ( which is a pa of primary health care) is provided at:- Village health unit Sub center and PHC. - Amongst these , PHC is the highest level.
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Which of the following is the 'Impact indicator' for evaluation of ASHA's performance?
exp: ASHA 25 - 45 yrs. Resident of same village Minimum 10th pass Requirement - 2/1000 Based on village level Trained by AWW + ANM for 23 days at PHC Impact indicator - 1. Reduction in IMR 2. Leprosy cases 3. PEM rates 4. TB cases
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Most common operation done by an Ophthalmologist in district hospital:
exp: Most common Ophthalmologic services at District hospital: Cataract surgery with IOL implantation is the most common surgery at District hospital ECCE + IOL is most commonly followed by phacoemulsifaction.
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Population norm for Health assistant in tribal areas:
exp: Health assistant (male) covers: 30,000 population in plains. 20,000 population in hilly/tribal areas. Also remember, population covered by: 1 Sub-center in plains- 5,000; Hilly/tribal areas- 3,000. 1 CHC in plains- 1,20,000 ; Hilly/tribal areas - 80,000.
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Which of the following Urban health post is attached to a hospital for sterilization, MTP & referral?
exp: Type D Health Post is attached to a hospital for sterilization, MTP and referral. Type A, B and C Health Posts are attached to a hospital for providing referral and supervisory services. Type D Health Post is attached to a hospital for sterilization, MTP and referral. Only type D health post have a post of medical officer. Types of Urban Health Post Population Range Type A less than 5,000, Type B between 5,000-10,000 Type C between 10,000-25,000 Type D between 25,000-50,000 *If the population is more than 50,000, then it is to be divided into sectors of 50,000 population and Health Posts are provided.
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Health guide works at the level of
exp: Village health guide (VHG)- Preferably a female, who is the permanent resident of the community and has minimal formal education upto 6th standard. -Training at : PHC (200 hours in 3 months) -Duties of VHGs: 1) Treatment of simple ailments 2) First aid 3) Mother and child health (with Family planning) 4) Health education 5) Sanitation -National target : 1 VHG per village (1000 rural population)
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: As per IPHS norms, the proposed number of Female health worker at Sub-center:
exp: Subcentre norms (IPHS) Manpower Existing Proposed Health worker (female) 1 2 Health worker (male) 1 1 Voluntary worker 1 (Optional) 1 (Optional) Total 2/3 3/4
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Role of ASHA in DOTS therapy:-
exp: ASHA is the central component of the national rural health mission (NRHM). Responsibilities of ASHA worker: Create awareness and mobilize community for local health planning Promote good health practices Counsel women on RCH Act as depot holder for essential medicines Act as DOTS provider Help develop a comprehensive village health plan Accompany pregnant women and children to the nearest health facility Be a pa of JSY and help reduce MMR.
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Under Home based New Born Care Programme, ASHA makes home visits for postnatal and new born care on:
exp: -Under NHM, ASHA makes home visits for postnatal and new born care on Day 3,7, 21, 28 & 42. - In case of home delivery she will make an additional visit on day 1. - The proposed incentive for ASHA is Rs 50 per home visit of around one hour duration, amounting to a total Rs.250 for five visits.
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Type B Sub-centre is characterized by:-
exp: SUBCENTERS TYPE-A TYPE-B Delivery facility Absent Present Health worker 1 1 Health worker /ANM 1 2 Safai karamchari 1 1 Total 3 workers 4
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Population covered under one Community Development Block is:
exp: One Community Development Block (ICDS) comprises of: Rural/Urban areas: 100,000 population (100 villages). Tribal areas: 35,000 population (550 villages).
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Urban Social Health Activist (USHA) workers are proposed to work for population of:
exp: URBAN SOCIAL HEALTH ACTIVIST (USHA):- Frontline community worker expected to deliver services at the doorstep in community. Link between Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) and urban slum population. 1 USHA worker per 1000-2500 population (250-500 households). Woman who resides in the slum, preferably 25-45 years age. Chosen through a community driven process involving urban local body of counselors, self - help groups, anganwadis.
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Which of the following workers is located at as sub-centre?
exp: Multi - purpose worker is located at: Sub - centre Anganwadi worker is located at: Village level or Urban slums ASHA is located at : Village level Health assistant is located at: PHC.
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms

question: Provision of total beds at PHC & CHC is:-
exp: - There are no beds at Sub-center level.
topic_name: Rural & Urban Health Centres, Workers, Norms
